sequel just to query graph like data is really really complex you're doing lots

relations that's what graph databases are for relational databases are inefficient
also for graph processing graphs tend to fan out very quickly as you as you as
you walk through the graph and that's really not what relational databases were built for they were built for
tables they're really good at that they can do joins between tables but but in
the kind of graph use cases the whig the way the data is stored the way the data
is processed is different than how it's done in a relational database and then
last but not least when you build a graph application you usually don't know what the ultimate scheme is going to be
the nice thing about graph database is it gives you a very natural way to evolve your application to add new data
to add new connections and in a relational database you have to define your schema and every time you want to
change something you have to basically you know redo your schema or you end up
implementing some kind of graph like schema that is more flexible but then it's not going to be efficient so
relational databases are great for many use cases but when you have use cases for a lot for highly connected data
relational databases really won't get the job done so what's a graph database
a graph database is a database that is really optimized for graph applications the way we store the data is optimized
the way we store the relationships the graph query languages are basically
built to be very natural for graph use cases and they're very fluid and
flexible so you don't have to you don't have to force the schema and you can basically evolve your application over

other emojis that you can choose when you actually you know like an article or something like that and
you know with a graph database you could just add that feature you wouldn't have to redo the schema or alter table or
anything so that's just a kind of example of how you know it is gonna be very easy for you to evolve these kind
of applications over time so there are two leading graph models in the market
one is called property graph and the other one is resource description framework or RDF and as we embarked on
this journey you know we asked customers in a which model would they prefer and
it became very clear to us quickly that even within the same organizations we have lots of use cases for both and so
in most cases today graph vendors kind of choose one or the other and basically
either do a property graph or do an RDF offering and we pretty quickly came to the conclusion that while it's not
always it's not always the right option to do you know both in this case it was
really the right thing to do because you know we sort of the same customers we're
needing both we also got to the conclusion that we could actually do both of them really really well so the

paradigm Neptune is purpose-built and it is optimized for both of these models
and that is really very very unique for Neptune there's really no other offering
in the market that has taken both of these models embraced them and and optimized these models in one database
the other thing that was really important to us is to embrace open API is the last thing we wanted to do is to

so we decided to embrace Apache tinker pop gremlin as the query language Apache
